26.02--W. J. Wilson, dau, b. ca. 1872 in MS; d. unk.; bd. unk.; m. unk.; unk. ch. [descendants possible]

[listed as W. J. Wilson, daughter, age 8, in 5 Jul 1880 census of Kemper Co., MS, and attending school]

[John M. Gwin Note--Feb 2015: Above is the entry I had at first, (based on the 1880 census) when Carrie Robison saw it on this page in March 2011. She contacted me, wondering if this were her g-gm, Welthia Jane. We found Welthia's husband-to-be in the same census, age 11, living near my E. B. Wilson family, which, of course, includes this W. J. If my entry for W. J. Wilson turns out to be the same as her Welthia Jane Wilson, then all the material in this box is correct, according to Carrie. And now in Feb 2015, we are making the call that our W. J. and Carrie's Welthia Jane are indeed the same person.]

ALONZO HICKS

PIEDMONT -- Alonzo D. Hicks, 73, of 108 Alabama St., Piedmont, died Sunday in an Anniston hospital after a long illness. Services will be Thursday at 3 p.m. at Mickelsen Brown-Service Mortuary with the Rev. Howard McBride and the Rev. Sanford Willis officiating. Burial will be in Jacksonville Cemetery.

Survivors include his wife, Mrs. Callie (sic) R. Hicks; a daughter, Mrs. Nell H. Stumbo of Oxford; three sons, Malcolm (sic) Hicks and Edwin Hicks, both of Eastaboga, and Benny (sic) Hicks of Oxford; three sisters, Mrs. Ola Crocker of Jackson, Miss., Mrs. Maggie Landrum, and Mrs. Minnie Wuillan, both of Meridian, Miss.; a brother, Frank Hicks of Meridian, Miss.; nine grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

Mr. Hicks was a native of Mississippi and lived in Piedmont 25 years. He was retired from Anniston Army Depot and was a member of the Baptist Church. The body will remain at the funeral home through services.

Nephews will be pallbearers.

In Memory of

CARRIE HICKS

OXFORD -- Graveside funeral services fo Carrie Ray Hicks, age 97, of Oxford, will be Thursday, Feb. 27, 2003, at 2:00 pm at Jacksonville City Cemetery with Revs. Rick Searle and William Cain officiating. The family will receive friends on Thursday from 11-1:00 pm at Miller Funeral Home. Mrs. Hicks died on Tuesday, February 25, 2003, at Regional Medical Center.

She is survived by Daughter Nell (Phil) Stumbo; Daughters-in-law Lenora Hicks and Johnnie Hicks; Grandchildren Angela King, Ronald Stumbo, Tammy Jacks, Terri Stricklin, Bonnie Charles, Melissa Horten, Carrie Robinson, and Mary Crouch; 17 great-grandchildren, and two great-great-grandchildren.

Mrs. Hicks was a resident of Calhoun County all of her life. She had worked as an LPN at Regional Medical Center. She was preceded in death by her husband, Alonzo Hicks; three sons: Malcolm D. Hicks, Benny P. Hicks and Edwin Durwood Hicks; and a grandson, Larry D. Hicks.

Pallbearers will be Phil Stumbo, Rick Jack, Gaines Ray, Morris Ray, Allen Stricklin, and Michael Gordon.

28.02--Malcoln Dewitt Hicks, b. 4 Oct 1926 in Deemer, Neshoba Co., MS; d. 10 Jun 1982; bd. Plum Springs Bapt. Ch. Cem. #02, Old Eastaboga, Talladega Co., AL--Find A Grave Memorial# 123509739; m. 11 Oct 1947 to Johnnie Eleanor O'Kelley [PRIVATE];

[listed as Malcoln Hicks, 4, b. in MS/MS/AL, in the 17 Apr 1930 census of Philadelphia Beat, Neshoba Co., MS]

OBITUARY

In memory of my precious dad, Malcoln D. Hicks, laid to rest June 1982.

Malcoln Dewitt Hicks, my precious daddy, was the son of Alonzo Dewitt Hicks and Carrie Wilbur Ray Hicks. Daddy was born in Deemer, Mississippi, but grew up in Calhoun County, Alabama. He served as an Army medic in the European Theatre during World War II.

Malcoln married Johnnie Eleanor O'Kelley on 11 Oct 1947. They had two children: Carrie Elizabeth and Mary Jean.

Malcoln Hicks was a dedicated Christian, a loving husband and father, and a man of strict integrity. He taught Sunday School classes for many years at Plum Springs Baptist Church (Eastaboga, Alabama). In addition to studying his Bible, his favorite hobby was fishing. He thoroughly enjoyed taking his young grandson, Chris, fishing with him. Sitting on the creek bank, communing with God and good friends, was Dad's way of relaxing.

Daddy was a loving father, a strict disciplinarian, and a man of high moral integrity. He loved his wife (Johnnie), his daughters (Carrie and Mary), and his four grandchildren (Chris, Keri, Allison, and Bethany) so very, very much.

We were blessed to have him as our husband, father, and grandfather.

He was, and is, greatly loved, and greatly missed. We know where he is, and we know he is no longer plagued by the evil cancer that took his earthly life. We WILL see him again, what a joy!

OBITUARY

Paul Zane Kemp passed away Saturday, November 7, 2020.

He was born November 6, 1928 in Steen’s log cabin at Apache Creek, New Mexico, to Benjamin William Kemp and Mary Jewell Johnson. He attended Reserve Union High School in Reserve, NM. He was salutatorian of his graduating class.

During the war years he worked for the Forest Service as lookout, trail worker and fire guard. In 1946 he entered New Mexico Highlands University and majored in pre-forestry.

Due to a knee injury, he changed his major to Art. He received a BA degree in 1950 and returned that fall to work toward a MA degree, but was drafted that November. He served in the Second Armored Division as an armored infantryman and was sent to the German Occupation Forces. His art worked on in the company day room enabled him to win first place in the division until the requirement of a pool table was made; none of the company day rooms was large enough to accommodate one.

After being discharged, he returned to New Mexico Highlands University for his MA degree and then taught art for three years at Montezuma County High School in Cortez, CO. In 1958 he attended Cranbrook Academy of Art in Michigan and received his MFA degree in 1960.

In 1961 Mr. Kemp joined the Art Department at Baylor University. The major duties included crafts (except ceramics), three-dimensional design, drawing, and sculpture. At various times he taught painting, printmaking, life drawing, and sections of art education. Mr. Kemp was a charter member of the Faculty Senate. He retired after 36 years at Baylor University.

Mr. Kemp was preceded in death by his parents, Benjamin William Kemp and Mary Jewell Johnson; his first wife, Lois Kelley Graham; his second wife, Katherine L. Wilson Peeples; sister, Mary Ellen Kemp; step-son Robert E. Peeples; son-in-law, Ronald J. Lee; and grandsons, Sean Michael Lee and Erick J. Lee.

He is survived by stepdaughter, Patricia A. Peeples-Lee of Waco; stepson, Richard O. Peeples and wife, Carolyn, of Waco; daughter-in-law, Elizabeth Peeples of West Covina, California; grandsons, Ronald J. Lee, Danial W. Lee; great-grandson, Joshua Lee; 10 grandchildren, 8 great-grandchildren and 4 great-great-grandchildren.

Lake Shore Funeral Home

[John M. Gwin Note: Cousin Tonya Wilson sent me the following obituary for Edna M. Crawford.]

Edna Marye Crawford

February 11, 1942 - November 19, 2014

Edna Marye Wilson Crawford, born February 11, 1942, in Vicksburg, Mississippi, passed away peacefully on November 19, 2014 surrounded by her family.

Marye loved family, friends, horses, and dogs, and rarely in that order. She would come to love countless pets over the years, with Belle her blue heeler at the top of the list. Her passion and commitment to those she loved knew no bounds.

She was a storyteller with a flair for the overly dramatic. She possessed and routinely exercised the uncanny ability to bring humor to situations that desperately needed it. In giving so much to others, there were times when Marye left little for herself. For the past six months, she faced improbable odds with a wry smile and a graceful blend of fear, hope, tears, sarcasm, and love for those near to her heart. She will forever live in our hearts, memories, and prayers.

She was preceded in death by her parents, Mittie Scott and Roger O'Neal Wilson; husband Jack William Crawford II, brother Robert Samuel Wilson, and sisters Katherine Louse Peeples Kemp and Agnes Effie Styles Simmons.

Those left to cherish her memory are brother Roger Bernard Wilson, sister O'Levia Neil Wiese, daughters Carmen Gayle Parker and husband Wayne, and Kimberly Lea Crawford, sons Jack W. Crawford III (Trae) and wife Amy, Roger Kelly Crawford and wife Lori, and Russell Travis Crawford, 15 grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

A memorial service will be held at 2:00 p.m. Saturday at Providence Funeral Home, 807 Carlos G. Parker Blvd. NW, Taylor, TX 76574.

In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hope for Horses Equine Rescue, mailing address 8853 FM 974, Bryan, TX 77808 or website: www.hopeforhorses.com.

OBITUARY

Tommie Joe Brooks, 67, of York, passed away Friday, Aug. 20, 2021, at his residence. He was born March 13, 1954, in Lauderdale County, Miss., to Hardy and Vera Mae Brooks.

He was a retired Asphalt Machine Operator for Mobile Asphalt Company. Survivors include his wife, Mitsy Ann Wright Brooks of York; his grandchildren: Landon, Madison, Aivley, and Blakeleigh; brothers, Danny Brooks of Nashville, Ga., Art Brooks of Little Rock, Miss., Timmy Brooks and Marvin Brooks both of Nashville, Ga.; sister, Doris Edge of Nashville, Ga.; a special niece, Angela "Angie" Grace of Lisman, Ala.; and a host of nieces and nephews.

He was preceded in death by his parents and his children, Stephanie Dawn and Tommie Joe II.

Due to the recent rise in Covid cases, a memorial service will be held at a later date.

Visit bumpesfuneralhome.com to sign the online register and post condolences to the family.

Lillie, Apr 1890; These three children are evidently the tail end of the family of E. B. and Estella A. Baxter Wilson 19 Jun 1900 Kellis Store, Kemper Co., MS Allen Hutton, 50, b. May 1850 in AL; Janie, 47, b. May 1853 in GA; Allie N., 11, son, May 1889;

Etta M., 8, dau, Oct 1891;

Virgie V., 6, dau, Apr. 1894; We know from the 9 Mar 1920 census of Sunflower Co., MS, that Agnes is Virgie's older sister, since Virgie Hutton, 24 (actually 26), sister-in-law, is living in the home of Robert B. and Agnes Hutton Wilson. Mr. Arbie Bennett Wilson, 90, died Sunday, December 11, 2011, at Winston Medical Center in Louisville, MS. Funeral services will be held at 2:00 P.M. Tuesday, December 13, at Porter Funeral Home, with interment in Memorial Park Cemetery. Visitation will be Monday from 5:00 to 8:00 P.M. at Porter Funeral Home. Mr. Wilson was a retired mechanic and a member of Salem Baptist Church in Kemper County. He is survived by a daughter, Mary Jo Woodward and husband Charles of Collinsville, MS; five sons, Robert Bennett and wife Rita Wilson of Louisville, Billy Ray and wife Connie Wilson of Louisville, Woodrow "Woody" and wife Marie Wilson of Starkville, Burbon Junior and wife Connie Wilson of Pulaski, MS, and Ricky and wife Jerry Wilson of Louisville; 11 grandchildren, and 18 great grandchildren. Memorials may be made to French Camp Academy, One Fine Place, French Camp, MS, 39745. To sign the guestbook, please go to www.porterfuneralhome.net.

Published in Clarion Ledger on December 12, 2011

Some Facebook messages of 11 Dec 2011:

John, just wanted to tell you that my grandpa passed away this morning. Tonya

Hi Tonya. I just got your message. Very sorry to hear about his going. I believe he would've been 90 in just a few weeks--is that right? John

We think he might have already been 90, and about to be 91. His birthday is listed as 1920 or 1921--the records in small towns in those days were not always accurate. My Aunt Jo (his daughter) has some letters her great-grandmother, not on the Wilson side, wrote to Mamie (his mother) mentioning that "Arbie was about 4 years old"; if we can find those letters, which have a postmarked envelope, we can tell what year it was. I've also seen that my great-grandfather Att passed away in May of '68 while other places say it was in December of that year. I think it was probably in May, and not recorded until December.

I am sad to see him go, but he's in heaven with Grandma; he got his life right with the Lord and apologized to all of the kids for anything hurtful he had done to any of them in the past; they all had a little more time together and got peace on a lot of things--we know that was God. I am glad that he's not in any more pain and has a sound mind again (he would come & go most days--that's another reason I know that time just before he passed was a gift from God).

A pastor once told me that when someone who is saved passes, it isn't really like a goodbye so much as it is an "I'll see you later", and that thought is making this a lot easier.

From: Brenda Preuss <bfpreuss at yahoo dot com>

Date: December 21, 2006

To: John Gwin <jmcdgwin@zianet.com>

Subject: Re: Estella Augusta Baxter Wilson's descendant

Hi John,

My grandmother was Lillie Florence (Wilson) Cook. My mother was Augusta Clytee Cook.

I live in Grass Valley, California. I have traveled to Alabama and Mississippi to visit family and to visit all the cemeteries and archives possible. I've also gone to Salt Lake City, UT, to the Mormon church to do a lot of research. Lucky for me all my ancestors, so far, came to the US from Scotland, England, and Ireland. I didn't have to learn to read another language to decipher old foreign records. My husband, John, studied German so he could read the old records.

Thanks for keeping me updated. Hope you have a great holiday season,

Sincerely,

Brenda Faye (Purvis) Preuss

28.01--Katherine Ann "Kathi" Cook; b. 21 Dec 1955 in Mobile Co., AL; d. 13 Feb 2012 in Birmingham, Jefferson Co., AL; bd. Mobile Mem. Gardens, Tillmans Corner, Mobile Co., AL--FAG #84988657; m. David Lee Empfield, Sr. (); three ch.;

OBITUARY

Mrs. Katherine Ann "Kathi" Cook Empfield - a native and resident of Mobile, AL died Monday, February 13, 2012 at the age of 56, at UAB Hospital in Birmingham, AL.

Kathi was preceded in death by her parents, Henry Wilson Cook and Bobbie Jean Goodloe Cook.

She is survived by her husband, David Lee Empfield, Sr.; three children, David Lee Empfield, Jr., Daniel Bryan Empfield, and Kristen Elizabeth Empfield; three sisters, Tina Cook (Jess) Savell, Pamela Cook Batley, and Cynthia Cook (Thomas) Guy; one brother, Timothy Wilson (Teresa) Cook; her aunt, Mary Ann (Bobby) Davis; nieces and nephews, Isabella Grace Savell, Garrett Batley, Shane Batley, Michelle Cook Masters, Scott Guy and Michael Guy; and her sisters in the Order of Polka Dots Mystic Society.

Funeral services will be held at 12 Noon on Friday, February 17, 2012 from the chapel of Radney Funeral Home, Saraland. The family will receive friends from 10 A.M. until 12 Noon on Friday at the funeral Home. Interment will be in Mobile Memorial Gardens.

Published in the Press-Register from Feb 14 to Feb 16, 2012
